_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: chlorinators, piping, regulators, chlorine dioxide generator

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Process Description

The water treatment process at the Winchester Water Treatment Plant involves the use of chlorine for disinfection purposes in order to provide safe drinking water to the city of Winchester and surrounding communities. For the first application point chlorine is mixed with sodium chlorite in order to generate chlorine dioxide, which is fed into the flash mix. For the second point of application chlorine, in its gaseous form, is mixed with treated water to form a chlorine solution that is added to water entering the clearwell.
Chlorine is listed by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as a regulated toxic substance. Facilities that handle amounts of chlorine over 2,500 pounds are required by the EPA to develop a Risk Management Program (RMP) to reduce the risk to employees and the public of injury from an accidental release of chlorine. The Winchester Water Treatment Plant will begin storing 8,000 pounds (four 2000 lbs cylinders) of chlorine by July 2006 and is therefore required to submit an RMP.  

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The policy of the City of Winchester is that the operation of all chlorine equipment will be by trained and knowledgeable personnel only. Therefore, personnel at the filter plant are required to attend all training as specified in the RMP. The emergency response policy involves providing emergency awareness level training to employees and the cooperation of the facility with the local emergency response agencies and AEDC.
 
Accidental Release Prevention Program

The Winchester Water Treatment Plant has developed an accidental release prevention program based on the EPA Risk Management Program and OSHA Process Safety Management regulations that includes the following:
   Operating procedures to ensure safe operation of the chlorine equipment 
   Annual operator training regarding the hazards of chlorine, operating procedures, and emergency procedures
   Routine maint

enance to prevent mechanical failure
   Leak detector to minimize the effects of an accidental chemical release
   Installation of a chlorine scrubber to neutralize any chlorine release that may occur

Five-Year Accident History

No accidental chlorine releases have occurred at the Winchester Water Treatment Plant in the last five years.

Emergency Response Program

The Winchester Water Treatment Plant is not currently included in the community emergency response plan developed by the Franklin County Emergency Management Agency. The primary responder in the event of an accidental chlorine leak is an AEDC response team. The water treatment plant has appropriate procedures in place to notify AEDC when there is a need to respond. 

Changes to Improve Safety

At the time this RMP was being developed the new chlorination system was not in operation. This newly designed system in combination with existing operating procedures, extensive training, and extremely conscientious operators adequately reduce the risk of accidental chemical releases. The installation of a chlorine leak detector in the chlorine dioxide room has been completed in order to further reduce the risk of accidential chemical release.
